issueDTO.title: Implement logical hadamard transition for the fixed boundary convention
issueDTO.description:
# Logical Hadamard Transition

The logical Hadamard transition allows X(Z) type correlation surface to be changed to Z(X) type either in space or time. The necessary ingredients to implement the feature is ready in the codebase and it should  be a good starting point for the new contributors to get themselves familiar with the project.

## 1. Temporal Hadamard Transition

### 1.1 Construction

The temporal Hadamard transition is simply a transversal layer of H gates applied to all data qubits. Note that the boundary conditions of the code patches before and after the transition are flipped, meaning the X(Z) boundary changes to Z(X), and the stabilizer types of the patch are also inverted.

![??????](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bc51a86a-1920-41d5-a23c-1da5cd0ce2cc)


### 1.2 Example

You can create a minimal example of a computation that includes the temporal Hadamard transition:

```py
from tqec import BlockGraph, Cube, Position3D, ZXCube, SignedDirection3D, Direction3D

g = BlockGraph()
g.add_edge(
    Cube(Position3D(0, 0, 0), ZXCube.from_str("ZXZ")),
    Cube(Position3D(0, 0, 1), ZXCube.from_str("XZX")),
)
correlation_surfaces = g.to_zx_graph().find_correration_surfaces()
g.view_as_html(
    pop_faces_at_direction=SignedDirection3D(Direction3D.Y, False),
    show_correlation_surface=correlation_surfaces[0],
)
```

![Temporal Logical Hadamard](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/68a2ac7a-b064-4da5-babb-a245734b4246)


## 2. Spatial Hadamard Transition

### 2.1 Construction

The spatial Hadamard transition is more complex. It involves replacing plaquettes on the boundaries of connected cubes. Specifically, new plaquettes measuring `ZXZX` and `XZXZ` stabilizers must be introduced at the boundary.

![??????](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d80ba83f-6d1d-4283-8707-00946ddcd5b0)


### 2.2 Example

You can create a minimal example of a computation that includes the spatial Hadamard transition with the following code:

```py
from tqec import BlockGraph, Cube, Position3D, ZXCube, SignedDirection3D, Direction3D

g = BlockGraph()
g.add_edge(
    Cube(Position3D(0, 0, 0), ZXCube.from_str("ZXZ")),
    Cube(Position3D(1, 0, 0), ZXCube.from_str("XZX")),
)
correlation_surfaces = g.to_zx_graph().find_correration_surfaces()
g.view_as_html(
    pop_faces_at_direction=SignedDirection3D(Direction3D.Y, False),
    show_correlation_surface=correlation_surfaces[0],
)
```

![Spatial Logical Hadamard](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9d0bc6fe-345f-4cf9-8dd6-46667a07d47b)

## 3. Implementation

To implement this feature, consider starting with the CSS-type surface code, which has a simpler circuit. The main changes will be in `src/tqec/compile/specs/library/_utils` particularly in the `default_substitution_builder` function. You will need to create new plaquettes that support the transition; existing plaquette builders can be found in `src/tqec/plaquette/library`, which you may modify as needed.

Regarding of temporal transition, there is an issue I'm aware of: if you implement a plaquette with a layer of H gates at the end of the circuit, i.e. after the measurements, then it will break the condition used by detector automation that there are no gates between measurements and resets. However, if you insert a layer of H gates before the measurements or after the resets, it will break the schedule of the circuits. @nelimee any idea on that? It seems reasonable to me that we should make some changes on the detector automation side to tolerate such cases.

For the boundary plaquette circuits that implement spatial transition, please refer to the figure above which includes both the stabilizer configuration and CNOTs order.  If further guidance is needed, I can provide sample circuits in [crumble](https://algassert.com/crumble).

Testing the implementation can be done using the example code above to generate a `BlockGraph`. Use the compilation pipeline from the README to create stim circuits, which you can then verify in Crumble.

These are just my initial thoughts on the issue; there may be some details I haven???t covered. If you run into any problems, please feel free to reach out here or via email :-)
comments:
This description is impressive, well done! 

> However, if you insert a layer of H gates before the measurements or after the resets, it will break the schedule of the circuits. @nelimee any idea on that? It seems reasonable to me that we should make some changes on the detector automation side to tolerate such cases.

There are two major issues here that I would like to discuss in the future (and probably not here):

1. There are a few "things" in the code that are hard-coded and require to match across several places right now. `Plaquettes` instances needing to be hand-made for each template (because each template might have its own plaquette indexing), template instantiation indices on the spatial boundaries, plaquette scheduling, and I am pretty sure that there are a few more things. We should think about whether this is fine for us, or if we should make that less manual / error-prone. I will open an issue on that soon.
2. The detector computation part could very much be improved. It is lacking tests, it is not really performant, we might even benefit from more features (i.e., being able to only compute detectors involving at least one measurement from a given set of measurements instead of computing all the detectors and filtering them afterwards). #378 might be a good start. I will also open the issues (or discussions) I have in mind about that soon.
Please, add SignedDirection3D, Direction3D to ??from tqec import BlockGraph, Cube, Position3D, ZXCube?? to make it easier to run for beginners as me :)

> Please, add SignedDirection3D, Direction3D to ??from tqec import BlockGraph, Cube, Position3D, ZXCube?? to make it easier to run for beginners as me :)

Thank you for the reminder! The code has been updated. Regarding the link mentioned in #436, I have removed the paragraph since the code snippets now work correctly with the latest branch.

@inmzhang do you know what's the actual link for https://qchackers.github.io/tqec/pull/322 ?
It's mentioned in the intro videos, but it's also broken. Thanks :)

> do you know what's the actual link for https://qchackers.github.io/tqec/pull/322 ?

This was the documentation preview page while the PR was still open, deployed [via this method](https://daiyi.co/blog/pr-previews-for-github-pages/). Now please refer to the latest docs page at https://tqec.github.io/tqec/.
Will this issue be closed by #562?

Yes, it should be. Not tested yet though.
@BSchelpe if I am right, that's the issue you are targeting. Could you comment here so that I can assign you to it?

Thanks! Yes when I'm done I think the last remaining piece of work on this will be finished. If you could assign me that would be great. I also think my PR (when I submit it :)) will close issue #631 .

issueDTO.title: Retire BoringCrypto and use Fips140.3
issueDTO.description:
ref: https://go.dev/doc/security/fips140

Right now, SPIKE binaries are created using CGO enabled and BoringCrypto experimental flag for FIPS compliance

Modern Go does not require BoringCrypto for FIPS and recommends using fips140 as mentioned in the reference link above.

This issue is about removing BoringCrypto and GCO_ENABLED=1 from where it makes sense (for example SPIKE Pilot does not need CGO, whereas SPIKE Nexus does because it uses SQLite) and use modern go alternatives.

repository.description: SPIKE is a lightweight secrets store that uses SPIFFE as its identity control plane. It protects your secrets and helps your ops, SREs, and sysadmins manage sensitive data securely with minimal overhead.
repository.name: spike

summary.main: Retire BoringCrypto and use Fips140 for FIPS compliance in SPIKE binaries
summary.validationOrRequirement: Use modern Go alternatives for FIPS compliance instead of BoringCrypto and CGO_ENABLED=1
summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned in the description or comments
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to FIPS compliance and recommends using fips140 instead of BoringCrypto, as per the reference link provided.

issueDTO.title: `raku` method returns invalid code for emoji enum members
issueDTO.description:
So, admittedly this is somewhat contrived (though I did stumble upon it by accident), but I believe this should work:

```raku
enum Directions <??????>; say Directions::<??????>.raku.EVAL;
```

However, it fails with:

```
===SORRY!=== Error while compiling /Users/julia/code/energieprijzen/EVAL_0
Bogus postfix
at /tmp/EVAL_0:1
------> Directions::?????????
    expecting any of:
        infix
        infix stopper
        statement end
        statement modifier
        statement modifier loop
```

This is because the `raku` method returns `Directions::??????`, which is not valid syntax. Now, [the documentation for the `raku` method](https://docs.raku.org/routine/raku#___top:~:text=For%20plain%20objects%2C%20it%20will%20conventionally%20return%20a%20representation%20of%20the%20object%20that%20can%20be%20used%20via%20EVAL%20to%20reconstruct%20the%20value%20of%20the%20object.) says (emphasis added)

> [i]t will **conventionally** return a representation of the object that can be used via [`EVAL`](https://docs.raku.org/routine/EVAL) to reconstruct the value of the object.

But I still think `raku` should always work for enum members, even though this is a bit of a weird case.
comments:
I think the problem is here:

https://github.com/rakudo/rakudo/blob/f7e1f3c47eeca2de691ad1eb219807b98473f827/src/core.c/Enumeration.rakumod#L17

We could fix it like this:

```raku
multi method raku(::?CLASS:D:) { sprintf '%s::<%s>', self.^name, $!key }
```

I've verified that this seems to work, but I don't know if it has any nasty side effects. Maybe we should do it conditionally?

Why use `sprintf`, when double quote string interpolation can do the work as well?
```raku
multi method raku(::?CLASS:D $self:) { "$self.^name()::<$!key>" }
```
Untested.

> Why use `sprintf`, when double quote string interpolation can do the work as well?

Just Go brain, I guess. But yes, I think that would work as well.
Then I suggest you make a PR for it, and add some tests in roast  :-)

repository.description: 🦋 Rakudo ??? Raku on MoarVM, JVM, and JS
repository.name: rakudo

summary.main: The `raku` method returns invalid code for emoji enum members, and the author believes that this should not be the case. The issue is about fixing this problem and making the `raku` method work correctly for enum members.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The `raku` method should always work for enum members, even though this is a weird case. The method should return a valid representation of the object that can be used via `EVAL` to reconstruct the value of the object.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author suggests a fix by modifying the `raku` method in the `Enumeration.rakumod` file. The fix involves using `sprintf` to format the output, but the author also suggests using double quote string interpolation as an alternative. The fix has not been tested.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about the `raku` method returning invalid code for emoji enum members. The problem is that the method returns `Directions::??????`, which is not valid syntax. The author suggests that the method should always work for enum members, even though this is a weird case. The issue is labeled as a good first issue.

issueDTO.title: Stop using SpanAttributes
issueDTO.description:
A lot of code imports semantic conventions attributes from `opentelemetry.semconv.trace.SpanAttributes` instead of the preferred `opentelemetry.semconv.attributes` and `opentelemetry.semconv.incubating`. 

Here's the list of of packages found grepping `SpanAttributes` on a recent checkout. Some packages may be more easy than others to convert since there may just be a couple of instances to fix.

People willing to help with this, state in the issue on what package you are going to work and you have 1 week to create a PR, after that we'll consider the package available to others.

The PR message should contains `Refs #3475` instead of `Fixes #3475`.

Updated of instrumentation specific tests in tests/opentelemetry-docker-tests should probably go on par with the conversion of the instrumentation package.

issueDTO.title: Hive metastore 4.0.1 remove deprecated thrift APIs
issueDTO.description:
### Apache Iceberg version

0.7.1

### Please describe the bug 🐞

Starting at version 4.0.1, Hive metastore removed deprecated thrift APIs that py-iceberg is currently using. When trying to create a table with `catalog.create_table_transaction` using Hive metastore 4.0.1, py-iceberg raise an unexpected `thrift.Thrift.TApplicationException: Invalid method name: 'get_table'` error:
```python
  File "iceberg.py", line 102, in create_table
    with self.catalog.create_table_transaction(
         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pyiceberg/table/__init__.py", line 289, in __exit__
    self.commit_transaction()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pyiceberg/table/__init__.py", line 766, in commit_transaction
    self._table._do_commit(  # pylint: disable=W0212
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pyiceberg/table/__init__.py", line 1638, in _do_commit
    response = self.catalog._commit_table(  # pylint: disable=W0212
               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pyiceberg/catalog/hive.py", line 457, in _commit_table
    hive_table = self._get_hive_table(open_client, database_name, table_name)
                 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pyiceberg/catalog/hive.py", line 331, in _get_hive_table
    return open_client.get_table(dbname=database_name, tbl_name=table_name)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/hive_metastore/ThriftHiveMetastore.py", line 4242, in get_table
    return self.recv_get_table()
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/hive_metastore/ThriftHiveMetastore.py", line 4260, in recv_get_table
    raise x
thrift.Thrift.TApplicationException: Invalid method name: 'get_table'
```
 This error seems related with this Hive PR(https://github.com/apache/hive/pull/3599) that removed the `get_table` method
comments:
Thanks for reporting this issue! 

I know there's an option to set `hive.hive2-compatible` to be compatible with Hive 2.x
https://py.iceberg.apache.org/configuration/#hive-catalog

Perhaps we need to do something similar for Hive 4.x

Do you know if there's a migration guide on interacting with Hive 4.x?

Ah we use hive 4.0.0 in the integration tests 

https://github.com/apache/iceberg-python/blob/24a0175d453fa50b2c40f9f2b53e53dbed3ab085/dev/docker-compose-integration.yml#L90-L92

https://github.com/apache/iceberg-python/blob/24a0175d453fa50b2c40f9f2b53e53dbed3ab085/dev/hive/Dockerfile#L26

Thanks for reporting this @mattheusv 

To get to the bottom of this:

- I would first suggest bumping the Hive container to 4.0.1
- Maybe regenerate the Hive Thrift files against the latest version, see https://github.com/apache/iceberg-python/tree/main/vendor

Let me add first-good-issue to see if anyone is interested in working on this 👍
@Fokko I can look into this
@akshayah3 That would be great! Let me know if you run into anything!
@akshayah3 Have you had a chance to look at this? I may be able to work on it if not

@rcsmith27 That would be great! As part of it, I think we also want to regenerate the HIve Thrift definitions: https://github.com/apache/iceberg-python/tree/main/vendor#hive-metastore-thrift-definition
qq is there a way to workaround this issue? We are using hive4 metastore and would like to use pyiceberg to manage data, but blocked by this issue.
@rkarthik29 it works if you use Hive 4.0.0. I can share how we build our Docker image if you want. We had to also change some of the AWS package versions so that IRSA on EKS would work.
@rcsmith27 Are you interested in pushing a fix to PyIceberg? It would be great to get this fixed 🚀
@Fokko I'd be happy to submit a fix for this. I should have time to finish it within the next two weeks.

@rcsmith27 Yes, please. It would be useful if you could share. Can it connect to the same backend database? Can I create my own metastore? I will use it mostly for reading and writing to existing tables; I will not create new tables.

issueDTO.title: Review of modules/digitalocean/droplet/main.tf file
issueDTO.description:
I noticed that the _null_resource.startup_configuration_ resource fails if **var.startup_script is NULL**.

Obviously, in our project, the value associated with startup_script is the VM setup script for Harvester deployment, so it is NEVER null.
However, when writing the test code, where I'm fine with startup_script being NULL, it fails.

```
??? Error: file provisioner error
??? 
???   with module.harvester_node.null_resource.startup_configuration,
???   on ../../../modules/digitalocean/droplet/main.tf line 106, in resource "null_resource" "startup_configuration":
???  106:   provisioner "file" {
??? 
??? source and content cannot both be null
```

I would consider one condition in this case:
```
count = var.startup_script != "" ? 1 : 0
```

issueDTO.title: Very poor errors when attempting to coerce Tensors with array types
issueDTO.description:
From Tizian

Here is a short reproducer:
shape = (4096 * 4096 * 8,)
tensor = spy.Tensor.empty(module.device, shape, 'half')
tensor.storage.copy_from_numpy(np.zeros(shape, dtype=np.float16))
tensor = tensor.with_grads(zero=True)

module['tensor_test_channels<8>'](tensor)
for
half[NumChannels] tensor_test_channels<int NumChannels>(half[NumChannels] data)
{
    [ForceUnroll]
    for (int i = 0; i < NumChannels; ++i)
    {
        data[i] = 2.h * data[i];
    }
    return data;
}
[1:55](https://nvidia.slack.com/archives/C07JB8BB7Q8/p1753707347775299?thread_ts=1753701420.569139&cid=C07JB8BB7Q8)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "D:\src\Falcor-nm-slangpy\external\slangpy\slangpy\core\function.py", line 348, in __call__
    return self.call(*args, **kwargs)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "D:\src\Falcor-nm-slangpy\external\slangpy\slangpy\core\function.py", line 231, in call
    return self._native_call(self.module.call_data_cache, *args, **kwargs)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "D:\src\Falcor-nm-slangpy\external\slangpy\slangpy\builtin\valueref.py", line 221, in create_output
    pt = slang_type_to_return_type(self.value_type)
         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "D:\src\Falcor-nm-slangpy\external\slangpy\slangpy\builtin\value.py", line 66, in slang_type_to_return_type
    raise ValueError(f"Slang type {slang_type} has no associated python value type")
ValueError: Slang type Object(0x1aa307d24f8) has no associated python value type
[1:58](https://nvidia.slack.com/archives/C07JB8BB7Q8/p1753707533301159?thread_ts=1753701420.569139&cid=C07JB8BB7Q8)
The other issue seems to be that I cannot pass a shape (N, N, 8) of half into that function. Only (N, N) of half[8].
new_buffer_channels_wrong = spy.NDBuffer(module.device, 'half',    shape=(128, 128, 8))
new_buffer_channels_right = spy.NDBuffer(module.device, 'half[8]', shape=(128, 128))
I can bypass this with some slightly more awkward
test = spy.NDBuffer.empty(module.device, shape=(4096, 4096), dtype='half[8]')
test.copy_from_numpy(array)
instead of
spy.NDBuffer.from_numpy(module.device, array)
(array.shape == (4096, 4096, 8))

issueDTO.title: Admin control to disable workspace creation for non-admin users
issueDTO.description:
### Scope & Context
This feature request is about providing administrators with control over who can create new workspaces. In certain deployments, it's necessary to centralize instance management by preventing non-admin users from creating their own workspaces.

The goal is to introduce a configuration setting that restricts the ability to create workspaces to admin-level users only.

### Current behavior
Currently, any authenticated user, regardless of their role, has the ability to create a new workspace. The option is available within the user's workspace management menu.

### Expected behavior
A new configuration setting should be introduced to allow administrators to disable workspace creation for non-admin users. This could be implemented either as an environment variable for the instance or as an option within the admin setup GUI.

When this setting is enabled:
* Only users with the 'admin' role will see the UI elements for creating a new workspace.
* For all other non-admin users, these UI elements will be hidden.
comments:
Hey B??uren, thanks for the suggestion. This couldn't really be at the Role level because a role is created in the context of a workspace while the workspace creation happens in a non logged-in state.
The only quick alternative is to introduce a system-wide environment variable like `IS_SIGNUP_DISABLED` that you would only toggle on temporarily when you need to switch a workspace (but anyone would still be able to do it)

I'm also interested this feature. Would this be something that can be implemented? An env var that will prevent anonymous users from creating workspaces...? IMO the ability to prevent anonymous users from creating workspaces from the login screen would be a great initial value add...and then the role level control could be considered/added to complete the feature.

This feature is especially useful in self-hosted scenarios, where we want to keep control of created workspaces (as one might need to configure them, and you have no access to workspaces created by other users unless invited or impersonating). As mentioned, I view this as a new environment variable that enables workspace creation only by the superuser.

OK so it could be something like `IS_WORKSPACE_CREATION_LIMITED_TO_WORKSPACE_ADMINS` (default `false` and ignored if no workspace exists yet).

It shouldn't be too difficult to implement, I'll let anyone who wants take a stab!

summary.attemptedFixes: Introduce a system-wide environment variable like `IS_SIGNUP_DISABLED` that you would only toggle on temporarily when you need to switch a workspace (but anyone would still be able to do it)
summary.otherNotes: This feature request is about providing administrators with control over who can create new workspaces. In certain deployments, it's necessary to centralize instance management by preventing non-admin users from creating their own workspaces.

issueDTO.title: [FEATURE] VolumeAttributesClass support for PVCs
issueDTO.description:
### Is your feature request related to a problem?
Currently, Once the persistent storage is configured, only the size can be adjusted. Other configurations like IOPS cant be modified.
One solution was to create a new storage class and create a new nodepool with that storage class and use smartscalar to move the data to this new nodepool.

### What solution would you like?
Now Kubernetes offers `VolumeAttributesClass` to modify the configs
Refer https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/storage/volume-attributes-classes/

Currently the CRD for PVCs for the cluster doesn't support VolumeAttributesClass.

issueDTO.title: [Refactor] Refactor SearchStats.Stats to use a builder pattern for non-breaking extensibility.
issueDTO.description:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

The `SearchStats.Stats` [class](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/index/search/stats/SearchStats.java), which is a public API, currently uses a constructor that accepts a long list of all the statistics it tracks. This design has a significant drawback: adding any new statistic requires modifying the constructor. Since this is a public API, any such modification is a breaking change for users of the library.

This makes it difficult to add new metrics and evolve the API without causing significant disruption for developers who have adopted it. Each new stat forces a major version bump and requires users to update their code, even if they don't need the new metric.

### Describe the solution you'd like

To resolve this, I propose refactoring the `SearchStats.Stats` class to use a builder pattern. This would involve:

1. Creating a Builder inner class within SearchStats.Stats.
2. The Builder class would have setter methods for each statistic 
3. A build() method in the Builder would construct the SearchStats.Stats object.
4. The existing constructor would be on deprecation path in 3.x and eventually made private in OpenSearch 4.0 since this will be a breaking change.

In OpenSearch 3.x, the existing constructor can continue to exist so as not to disrupt any depending plugins or otherwise.



### Related component

Libraries

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Having setter methods for new stats or existing stats risks the immutability of the object.

### Additional context

Identified as part of adding new search metrics: https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/pull/18707 where backward compatibility is failing because of this.
comments: @sandeshkr419 I would like to work on this ticket.

Thanks @pavanteja-potnuru for your interest here.

While I was working on https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/pull/18707 I realized that I would not want the code quality to degrade with me introducing a new constructor for my use-case, so I ended up including the builder pattern changes mentioned in this issue https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/issues/18723 already as part of https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/pull/18707 - so most likely this issue will close itself since the changes will be part of https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/pull/18707 itself.

(sorry - should have not put this up as `good-first-issue` if I was probably gonna work on it anyway)
@sandeshkr419 Okay, np.
[Catch All Triage](https://github.com/opensearch-project/.github/blob/main/TRIAGING.md) - [1](https://github.com/krisfreedain) [2](https://github.com/andrross)

This feature needs to also update the documentation to reflect the new charts and their values and how to configure them.

issueDTO.title: Can we please have up to date manual installation docs?
issueDTO.description:
Hi Everyone,

I've tried following the manual install instructions on the website twice now and I've had to resort to docker each time. While docker is convenient for installation, operation and management is not ideal with docker. I've had to troubleshoot the timeline not working and the map not working a couple times, each time has been especially onerous compared to other photo gallery applications without Docker. 

Thanks! 


Tmanok
comments:
Hi @tmanok, thanks for reporting the issue.
The source of truth is the Readme in this repo. The docs website might be a bit (or more) outdated, and we'd appreciate contributions to keep it up-to-date.

While we still support direct deployment on the host, we recommend Docker-based deployment as the main way to install Photoview, as it gives perfect abstraction and unification across host OS and architectures. Nothing is ideal, but the Docker deployment is easier to maintain, so the direct deployment on the host is considered an advanced way for users, skilled and ready to solve some dependency and configuration issues, caused by their OS and architecture differences and nuances.

Thanks for the quick reply, I really appreciate that you took the time to write to me in addition to volunteering to make this project a reality. I've setup "Dockage" partly to learn another tool, partly to speed things up by skipping some of the docker-specific commandline. Some of my issues with the timeline were simply filesystem permissions on the host as it turns out, which is a bit embarassing to overlook. However, after resolving the permissions, it also took renaming the folders to get PhotoView to re-synchronize the timeline and eliminate blank images in it. It's working as expected now! 

Thank you again for the time and effort you put into this completely free and life improving software!

Tmanok

Yes, I know that setting proper permissions for Photoview on the host FS level might not be so straightforward and clear for some of our users. I tried to describe the permission requirements as detailed as I was able to, providing alternative ways to make it work (creating a user with the same UID and GID or giving a read permission to everyone). However, I understand that this might still cause some misunderstanding.

> it also took renaming the folders to get PhotoView to re-synchronize the timeline and eliminate blank images in it

I didn't get this part: which folders did you have to rename? As far as I remember, if some media files fail to be scanned and appear with blank thumbnails, they should be scanned again by the following scan job run until they are successfully scanned or removed from the media library folder. So, in your case, once you fixed your host FS permissions, you just need to run the scan job again from the Settings page, and after it is finished, those files should appear with their thumbnails on the Timeline.

Hi @kkovaletp, 

The media folders containing individual albums of photos needed to be renamed to be re-scanned properly. It was very strange but because the permissions were wonky and I hadn't noticed (uploaded with wrong user, didn't give read permission to everyone rw- r-- ---) PhotoView couldn't read the files, but could list them so blank thumbnails appeared and incomplete albums were present. After changing the permissions, forcing a sync for all photos owned by my user (the only application user in PhotoView), it did not update the files. Eventually, weeks later when I had time again, I decided to try simply renaming the folders containing those broken images and voila it rescanned them properly. 

It seems like PhotoView is very good at detecting new media, but sometimes it might be sticky about old media. Fortunately, it doesn't retain things that have been deleted. Admittedly, I wish I could delete photos right in the web-application instead of on the filesystem (sometimes I find duplicates after I upload to PhotoView and it's my publication server for family photos, not my archive or source of truth storage). 

Thanks again for your help and time contributing to the project. I'll leave the "issue" open until your next reply just in case you want me to help replicate the behaviour I described. 


Tmanok

issueDTO.title: Customizable HTTP user agent (suffix?)
issueDTO.description:
This is @robjarawan's idea.

It would be nice to be able to customize the HTTP user agent.

https://github.com/MetPX/sarracenia/blob/dc3b0f539b2f6741a01b90c494eece9a7ab86c01/sarracenia/transfer/https.py#L352

I personally think it would be best to only support a suffix that can be added to the existing `Sarracenia $version` user agent.
comments: I also agree with your remark. Removing the `Sarracenia $version` would give users the ability to spoof the program.

Lads just to clarify: my suggestion is not to allow full override of the user-agent string, keeping the sr $version prefix is important for integrity and traceability etc

Just the ability to append a short user-defined suffix to the existing user-agent, such as an identifier for an organization/individual or dev:

Example:
Sarracenia 3.2.1 my-team-name or Sarracenia 3.5.8 geomet-srv01-james

that would help distinguish traffic in logs and metrics without enabling spoofing or hiding the actual sr version :)

summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned in the description or comments

## Resources

Example -> [Transfers and Actions page](https://docs.near.org/build/smart-contracts/anatomy/actions) uses the type Balance. This is no longer a valid type and should be updated to NearToken

The current `headless` parameter in `browser.start()` should be deprecated in favor of a more consistent approach using an `Options` object with a dedicated headless property. This refactor involves marking the old parameter as deprecated, updating the code to read headless mode from Options.headless, and updating documentation accordingly.

This change centralizes browser configuration, improving maintainability and extensibility without breaking backward compatibility immediately.

issueDTO.title: CI: increase visibility on flaky tests in PRs
issueDTO.description:
## Description

In https://github.com/camunda/camunda/issues/28504 we identified that our current policy of passing a build even if flaky tests are present (to avoid blocking engineers) reduces visibility on flaky tests. This may lead to situations where e.g. in PRs the CI are green, but new flaky tests get introduced, or existing tests got more flaky.

## Goal

To avoid this we should increase visibility of flaky tests in PRs to make the author and reviewer more aware and ask them to check whether their PR contributes to the flakiness (and fix that if so). This could be done e.g. with in-place updated PRs comment(s) for flaky tests like demonstrated in https://github.com/camunda/camunda/pull/28834

We should aim to keep noise as low as possible.
comments:
WHAT TO DO NEXT:

- [x]  Give a look into old CI runs, specialy into analyze-test-run step to see it in action
- [x]  Add the `peter-evans/find-comment@v3` step
- [x]  Add the `peter-evans/create-or-update-comment@v4` step
- [x]  Format the comment body with markdown and helpful context
- [x]  Test it on a sample PR with forced flaky output to validate
@cmur2 I would like to register here a few ideas I had for future improvement:

- Strict PR Blocking on Flakiness
- Introduce a ???critical flake??? classification
- Maybe flag as ???new??? flaky tests (requires historical tracking)
- I don't know how much of visibility we will get, but we could think of using GH Checks instead of comments, like [demo here](https://josh-ops.com/posts/using-github-checks-api/)
  - maybe it will make more sense when we pair it up with annotations like the one used in CodeQL 
- Positive feedback when flaky tests are fixed/removed

Also a question, currently do we differentiate flaky vs broken tests?
> a few ideas I had for future improvement

@liliancavalet Nice, those are all very desirable ideas to implement!

> I don't know how much of visibility we will get, but we could think of using GH Checks instead of comments, like [demo here](https://josh-ops.com/posts/using-github-checks-api/)

This is actually something you can evaluate as part of this ticket already as it is in-scope. The mechanism to use/update comments is just listed as an example, alternatives are possible and if you want to explore/compare them that is perfect.

> Strict PR Blocking on Flakiness

I'd say on "new" flakiness/flaky tests, to avoid introducing more ??? with such a hurdle we'd naturally decrease flakiness caused by code changes in the overall system.

> Maybe flag as ???new??? flaky tests (requires historical tracking)

We have that kind of historical info present via [CI Health metrics](https://github.com/camunda/camunda/wiki/CI-&-Automation#flaky-tests) already, so this is definitely something worth looking into.

> Also a question, currently do we differentiate flaky vs broken tests?

Yes, the naming used [on this dashboard](https://dashboard.int.camunda.com/d/ae2j69npxh3b4f/flaky-tests-camunda-camunda-monorepo) is on "flaky" (successful on retries) vs "failing" (not successful even after several retries) tests. We have the data already, for jobs that send it.
## WHAT TO DO NEXT (Prioritized Plan)

### 1. Investigate Existing CI Behavior
- [x] Look into old CI runs, especially the `analyze-test-run` step, to understand current behavior and outputs.
eg.: https://github.com/camunda/camunda/actions/runs/16110382851/job/45452573611

### 2. Implement Comment-Based Feedback (Baseline)
- [x] Add `peter-evans/find-comment@v3` step.
- [x] Add `peter-evans/create-or-update-comment@v4` step.
- [x] Format the comment body using **markdown**, with clear, helpful context and summary of flaky tests.
- [x] Test this on a **sample PR** with **forced flaky output** to validate functionality and formatting.

### 3. Explore GitHub Checks as an Alternative (Optional / Parallel)
- [x] Evaluate using **GitHub Checks API** for displaying flaky test information.
- [x] Reference: [Using GitHub Checks for Test Feedback](https://josh-ops.com/posts/using-github-checks-api/)
- [x] Compare against the comment-based approach:
  - Visibility
  - UX for developers
  - Integration complexity
- [x] (Optional) Provide both implementations or document trade-offs in the ticket/PR.

### 4. Plan for Strict PR Blocking on New Flakiness (Future Scope)
- [ ] Consider blocking PRs that introduce **new flaky tests** (not existing ones).
- [ ] Flag **???new??? flaky tests** using historical data from CI Health metrics.

**Recap and Next Steps**

Here's a quick recap of where we are and what the plan looks like moving forward:

🔍 Summary of the Discussion
- We've been exploring how to guide PR authors when flaky tests are detected.
- The current approach is intentionally non-blocking, aiming to observe how engineers respond before enforcing stricter policies.
- A key point raised was that messages containing ???if you have time??? phrasing, might lead engineers to dismiss the warning, even if their PR could have introduced the flakiness.
- There's consensus that we should ask authors to assess whether their change could be related to the flaky test 
- There's also awareness that flaky tests can arise even without directly touching test-related code, so context is key.

🧭 Planning Ahead
To ensure we strike the right balance between signal and noise, and avoid jumping to premature enforcement. I decided to take an incremental and feedback-driven approach:

??? **Current state:** Informational comments will be available, without blocking.

??? **Observation period:** Over the next month, I will monitor how engineers interact with these comments, and start a thread at the end of the period to everyone bring their insights.

🔁 **Re-evaluation:** Based on that feedback, we???ll decide whether to:

- Enforce blocking for new flaky tests,
- Keep messaging as-is,
- Highlight newly introduced flakiness & easily direct user to files with flaky tests 
- Or explore other options

I've already set a reminder for next month to revisit this thread and assess how it???s going. 
~For now, I???ll keep this task open, since we still have an [ongoing discussion about the noisy caused by the comments.](https://github.com/camunda/camunda/pull/35780#issuecomment-3117863746)~
After internal alignment, we've decided to take this [other approach](https://github.com/camunda/camunda/pull/35780#issuecomment-3127753493), although the overall plan described above remains unchanged.

Thanks again, @cmur2 and @maxdanilov, for your support and for the insightful discussions!

issueDTO.title: [Good First Issue] Support All SQL Functions in Other SQL System
issueDTO.description:
### Search before asking

- [x] I had searched in the [issues](https://github.com/apache/doris/issues?q=is%3Aissue) and found no similar issues.


### Description

We plan to implement all SQL functions in other famous DBs, like MySQL, PG, Trino, CK, Hive, and more. Facilitate the users to migrate to Doris. They're very suitable for newcomers as your first Doris PR. So here's the list. Feel free to comment to pick anyone! If one is picked, I will tick it.

## Part I. Hive

- [x] sinh(from Trino), asinh, atanh, acosh (Easy) @ChenMiaoi 
- [ ] context_ngrams @noixcn 
- [ ] factorial (Easy)
- [ ] levenshtein
- [ ] encode, decode
- [ ] soundex

See the newest Hive document for these functions' explanation.

## Part II. Spark

- [x] map_concat  (been taken for interview @HappenLee )
- [ ] regexp_extract_all for the third argument @Djanghao 

## Part III. Trino&Presto

- [x] regexp_count, regexp_position (been taken for interview @HappenLee )
- [ ] hamming_distance (better with levenshtein together)
- [ ] human_readable_seconds
- [ ] timezone_hour, timezone_minute
- [ ] GEO FUNCTIONS
    - [ ] ST_GeomFromKML
    - [ ] ST_Equals, ST_Relate
    - [x] ST_Intersects, ST_Disjoint, ST_Touches @koi2000 
    - [ ] ST_Crosses, ST_Overlaps, ST_Relate, ST_Within
    - [ ] ST_Buffer, ST_Boundary, ST_Envelope, ST_EnvelopeAsPts, ST_ExteriorRing
    - [ ] geometry_nearest_points, geometry_union, ST_Union
    - [ ] ST_Difference, ST_Intersection, ST_SymDifference
    - [ ] ST_Centroid, ST_ConvexHull
    - [ ] ST_CoordDim, ST_Dimension
    - [ ] ST_Distance, ST_GeometryType, ST_Length
    - [ ] ST_InteriorRingN, ST_InteriorRings, ST_NumInteriorRing
    - [ ] ST_GeometryType, ST_IsClosed, ST_IsEmpty, ST_IsSimple, ST_IsRing, ST_IsValid
    - [ ] ST_PointN, ST_StartPoint, ST_EndPoint, ST_Points, ST_XMax, ST_XMin, ST_YMax, ST_YMin
    - [ ] simplify_geometry
    - [ ] ST_NumGeometries, ST_Geometries, ST_NumPoints
- [ ] ARRAY FUNCTIONS
    - [ ] dot_product @meox3259 
    - [ ] trim_array
    - [ ] ngrams
    - [ ] combinations
    - [ ] reduce (lambda function) @cypppper 
    - [ ] sort (add the three arguments with lambda functor version) (Hard)
- [ ] merge(HLL)
- [ ] typeof
- [ ] Aggregation Functions
    - [ ] bool_or, bool_and

## Part IV. DuckDB

- [ ] Math Functions
    - [ ] even @wumeibanfa 
    - [ ] gcd, lcm @wumeibanfa 
    - [ ] gamma
    - [ ] signbit @wumeibanfa 
- [ ] String Functions
    - [ ] ord @CAICAIIs 
- [ ] Vector(Array) Functions
    - [ ] cross_product
    - [ ] cosine_similarity
- [ ] Date Functions
    - [ ] century
- [ ] Aggregation Functions
    - [ ] geomean @0AyanamiRei 
    - [ ] entropy
    - [ ] sem
    - [ ] skew_pop, kurt_pop
- [ ] Map Functions
    - [ ] map_contains_entry @DayuanX 
    - [ ] map_entries @DayuanX 

## Others

- [ ] json_search with 4th and 5th arguments like MySQL @ChenMiaoi 

More tasks is coming...

## Solution

**All the guidelines to implement an SQL function are in https://github.com/apache/doris/issues/48201. Please take a carefully look at!**

issueDTO.title: Chatbot Integration
issueDTO.description:
###  Feature Request: Chatbot Integration in Brevity

**Goal**
Develop a smart chatbot inside the Brevity app that allows users to:
- Ask for summaries or explanations of articles
- Clarify news topics (fact-checking assistance)
- Engage in basic conversation for better news understanding

---

**Proposed Approach**
- Use **Gemini API** or **OpenAI GPT-4 API** as the backend brain
- Create a new screen or floating chatbot UI (like a chat bubble)
- If needed, add a backend Firebase Function (or prepare for future Node.js use)

---

**User Flow**
1. User taps on a chat icon in the app
2. A modal/chat screen opens
3. User types a question or news-related prompt
4. Chatbot responds using the Gemini API
5. Past conversations can optionally be stored locally or in Firestore

---

**Tech Stack**
- Dart / Flutter
- flutter_bloc for state management
- Gemini API via HTTP

---

**UI Ideas**
- Floating Action Button ??? Chat Overlay
- Chat bubble layout (like WhatsApp/Messenger)
- Show loading shimmer while bot "thinks"
- Support image/news link previews in chat

---

**Why Me?**
I'm a GSSoC contributor excited about Flutter, NLP, and building helpful AI tools. I'd love to implement the first version of this chatbot and iterate based on mentor feedback.

Please assign this issue to me.
comments:
Hey! Thanks for the suggestion ??? the chatbot integration has actually already been implemented!

However, what???s missing right now is proper testing. If you???re up for it, we???d love your help testing the chatbot and reporting any bugs, edge cases, or suggestions to improve the interaction.

Let us know if you're interested, and we can guide you on how to get started. Appreciate the initiative!

issueDTO.title: Implement CompareFn for ByteBoolEncoding by comparing &[bool]
comments:
Hi, please provide more information about this issue, and I can help implement it.

Have searched in the codebase, there is no `ByteBool`, only `ByteBoolArray` in `encodings/bytebool/src/array.rs`

@klion26 apologies for the delay

The task is about this compute function: 

https://github.com/vortex-data/vortex/blob/d88fc23459c362f3ebce4a274169538fcb6698a8/vortex-array/src/compute/compare.rs#L123-L130

Roughly, the way it works is that by checking different `CompareKernel` - if some of them produces the result, that'd be the output of that function

That's the example of `CompareKernel` implementation: 
https://github.com/vortex-data/vortex/blob/d88fc23459c362f3ebce4a274169538fcb6698a8/vortex-array/src/arrays/varbin/compute/compare.rs#L20

You can notice that this kernel is implemented by many arrays but not for boolean array (there is no `impl CompareKernel for BoolVTable`). The task is to implement that 🙂

issueDTO.title: Advanced example with streaming INSERT
issueDTO.description:
We currently provide examples for streaming from file https://github.com/ClickHouse/clickhouse-js/blob/72f490a6faf894deb723f2c6d5b7cdee75177def/examples/node/insert_file_stream_ndjson.ts

However, the examples don't cover a use case when a user app pushes to the `values` stream and should handle the backpressure mechanism correctly. If user app doesn't implement backpressure handling, it might lead to problems like these  https://github.com/ClickHouse/clickhouse-js/issues/135

* There currently exist 17 different functions for matching modules/parameters. Let's consolidate this logic by using only the functions defined in [utils/match.py](https://github.com/neuralmagic/compressed-tensors/blob/main/src/compressed_tensors/utils/match.py)

Function | Used for/by | Maps to
-- | -- | --
get_layer_by_name | awq | attrgetter(layer_name)(module)
get_layers_params | pruning modifiers | match_named_parameters
get_param | None | Delete
get_params | get_layers_params , get_param | Delete
set_layer | Distillation modifier | Module.set_submodule
get_layer | None | Delete
get_layers | Lots | match_named_modules
match_layers_params | get_layers | Delete
get_default_params | match_layers_params | Delete
match_targets | Many | match_named_modules
get_quantizable_layers | match_layers_params | Delete, use explicit targets
get_prunable_layers | match_layers_params | Delete, use explicit targets
get_terminal_layers | match_layers_params | Delete, use explicit targets
get_matching_layer | Smoothquant | match_modules_set
AWQ.set_resolved_mappings | AWQ | match_modules_set
match_modules | sequential pipeline | match_named_modules
get_linear_layers | infer_sparsity_structure_from_model | match_named_modules

issueDTO.title: Add title/aria-label attribute to components that include icon buttons
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the feature in detail (code, mocks, or screenshots encouraged)

Building off of https://github.com/skeletonlabs/skeleton/issues/3588

We should aim to do a pass through the Skeleton components that implement `btn-icon` and ensure these have the appropriate props to set both the `title` and `aria-label` attribute per each. Additionally, each prop should contain a default value. The idea is these labels should describe the action in as succinct a manner possible in English. But given they are a prop so they can modified as needed for i18n purposes.

### How to Update

Setting up a new component props has a few steps:

> NOTE: remember to keep both the Svelte (.svelte) and React (.tsx) components in sync

1. Add an optional prop to the component's respective `types.ts` file
2. Add a semantic JSDoc description for each prop in `types.ts`
3. Register the new prop in the component and set a default value
4. Add the prop to the template for each icon button

We do no have a naming convention for `title` or `aria-label` attributes at present, but we should be able to keep these similar to [style prop conventions](https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/resources/contribute/components#style-prop-conventions):

- If the icon button is the root element -> no prefix needed
- If the icon button is a child element -> prefix as `fooTitle` and `fooAriaLabel`

Where `foo` represents the semantic prefix name already in use for class props, derived from Zag's spread methods, or if need be a new semantic name can be implemented.

### Attribute Presets

Per the attribute values themselves, remember they should describe the purpose of the button, not just summarize the icon, especially the `aria-label` for screen reader users.

- BAD: `title="Arrow"` -> this does not describe the purpose of the button
- GOOD: `title="Submit"` -> this is a good and semantic description of the button

### What type of pull request would this be?

Enhancement

### Provide relevant links or additional information.

The following components were reported to make use of the `btn-icon` class in .svelte/.tsx files, but I'd welcome a new dedicated audit to confirm.

> NOTE the component is the focus of this request, maintaining the playground is optional (but welcome)

```
- packages/skeleton-svelte/src/components/Toast/Toaster.svelte
- playgrounds/skeleton-svelte/src/routes/components/app-bars/+page.svelte

comments: Hi! I'd like to work on this issue. Can I have it?

@mdebbar @natebiggs is there any reason we don't start DWDS for profile mode? I'm not terribly familiar with the difference between debug and profile mode for web. Is profile mode basically an alias for release mode for web targets?

Only debug mode targets ddc. Profile and release mode both target dart2js when the `flutter run` command is used (and wasm is not specified):
https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/packages/flutter_tools/lib/src/isolated/resident_web_runner.dart#L358

We might pass some different flags to dart2js in profile mode vs release mode. But either way it's dart2js so there's no devtools debugging capabilities.

issueDTO.title: [Refactor] Move type-only imports under `if TYPE_CHECKING`
issueDTO.description:
We should refactor the codebase to improve how typing-related imports are handled. Currently, some imports that are only used for type annotations are being loaded at runtime unnecessarily. Python provides the `TYPE_CHECKING` constant from the typing module exactly for this use case.

The goal is to wrap these imports in an `if TYPE_CHECKING` block, so they are available to type checkers like MyPy or Pyright, but ignored during execution. This helps reduce startup time, prevents circular import issues, and avoids bringing in dependencies that aren???t actually needed at runtime.

This refactor is purely structural and doesn???t affect behavior. It???s mostly about cleanup and making the typing layer more efficient and idiomatic.

issueDTO.title: [CLI] Advanced settings modification requires replacing all settings one-by-one
issueDTO.description:
## Problem
When modifying advanced settings in the CLI, users cannot change individual settings. Instead, they must replace all settings one-by-one, even if they only want to change a single value.

## Current Behavior
- `/settings` ??? Advanced ??? User must input all settings again
- Cannot selectively modify just one setting (e.g., only the API key)
- Forces users to re-enter all configuration values

## Expected Behavior
- Allow selective modification of individual settings
- Show current values and allow users to keep existing values
- Provide options like "Keep current value" or show defaults

## User Experience Impact
- Frustrating when only wanting to change one setting
- Risk of introducing errors when re-entering all values
- Time-consuming for users with complex configurations

## Technical Context
The issue is in the settings modification flow in `openhands/cli/settings.py`, specifically in the `modify_llm_settings_advanced()` function.

## Proposed Solutions
1. **Interactive setting selection**: Allow users to choose which settings to modify
2. **Current value display**: Show existing values and allow keeping them
3. **Incremental updates**: Only prompt for settings the user wants to change

## Related Files
- `openhands/cli/settings.py` (modify_llm_settings_advanced function)
- `openhands/cli/commands.py` (handle_settings_command function)

issueDTO.title: [Feature] Add static HTML test pages for deterministic integration testing
issueDTO.description:
To improve the reliability of the project, we should create static HTML and CSS pages that live inside the project itself. That way, we???re not depending on external servers or network conditions, which makes the tests faster and fully deterministic. The goal is to cover scenarios like opening and closing the browser, querying elements, performing clicks, handling navigation, and other core behaviors, all within a controlled environment. These pages could be stored in a dedicated folder and used during test runs via local file access or a lightweight internal server if needed. This approach would give us much more confidence in the stability of the tool and avoid flaky behavior caused by unpredictable remote content.

Potential structure:

```markdown
tests/
  integration/
    test_open_close_browser.py
    ...
  pages/
    basic_interaction.html
    dom_mutation.html
    form_submission.html
    ...
```

issueDTO.title: [Bug]: The search API Key gets reset when you save settings
issueDTO.description:
### Is there an existing issue for the same bug? (If one exists, thumbs up or comment on the issue instead).

- [x] I have checked the existing issues.

### Describe the bug and reproduction steps

* Add a search API Key and save changes.
* Then change something in the settings. Let's say you change the LLM Provider and Model
* Click Save Changes.
* The Search API Key gets reset

### OpenHands Installation

Docker command in README

### OpenHands Version

_No response_

### Model Name

_No response_

### Operating System

None

### Logs, Errors, Screenshots, and Additional Context

_No response_
comments:
This looks like a **straightforward bug** that should be relatively manageable to fix. The issue has a clear, reproducible problem: the search API key gets wiped out whenever settings are saved, even when modifying unrelated configuration like LLM provider settings.

**What's clear from the report:**
The reproduction steps are well-defined - add a search API key, change any other setting, save, and the API key disappears. This suggests a classic form handling issue where either the search API key field isn't being properly included in the save operation, or there's a state management problem where the key gets overwritten during the settings update process.

**Technical factors to consider:**
This is likely a UI/UX issue in the settings form logic. The problem could stem from a few common patterns - maybe the form is only serializing visible or "dirty" fields, or there's separate state management for different setting categories that aren't being merged properly. It could also be a simple oversight where the search API key field isn't included in the save payload.

**What needs investigation:**
You'll want to examine the settings form component and trace through the save flow. Check how form data is collected, whether all fields are being included in the request, and how the backend processes the settings update. Look at the network requests when saving to see if the API key is even being sent.

**Next steps:**
Start by reproducing the issue locally, then inspect the settings save functionality in the frontend code. Check the form serialization logic and the API call that handles settings updates. This feels like the kind of bug where the fix might be adding a single field to a form data object or ensuring proper state merging.
I'm on it! mamoodi can [track my progress at all-hands.dev](https://app.all-hands.dev/conversations/cd964620c9db45c08a0a4241c0e73aa4)
@mamoodi is this still an issue? It looks like the PR above was closed.
Yep @michaldorsett still an issue. The PR was not merged.
@mamoodi why not? is it that the bot did not actually resolve it?

@michaldorsett no it wasn't successful. The settings page is a little intertwined and I think it's going to go through an overhaul at some point so didn't want to pursue it further since it's a minor bug.
@mamoodi So perhaps it's best to remove the `good first issue` label, and somehow mark this as `backlog`?
Why has this issue persisted for so long without being resolved? Has no one discovered this problem while using custom LLM interfaces?
Because it's a minor issue. Also I don't think most people are using the Tavily search API Key field.

issueDTO.title: [CLI] Settings changes require restart even when no session is active
issueDTO.description:
## Problem
Settings changes require a restart to take effect, even when no session has been started yet. This creates unnecessary friction in the setup process.

## Current Behavior
- User modifies settings via `/settings`
- CLI shows "They will take effect after restart"
- Restart is required even if no agent session is running

## Expected Behavior
- Settings should take effect immediately when no session is active
- Only require restart when an active session would be affected
- Provide immediate feedback when settings are successfully applied

## User Experience Impact
- Adds unnecessary steps to initial setup
- Confusing when no session is running
- Breaks the flow of configuration

## Technical Context
The settings are loaded at startup in `main_with_loop()` and not reloaded during runtime. The configuration could be reloaded when no session is active.

## Proposed Solution
1. **Immediate application**: Apply settings immediately when no session is running
2. **Smart restart detection**: Only require restart when an active session exists
3. **Clear messaging**: Different messages based on whether restart is actually needed

## Related Files
- `openhands/cli/main.py` (settings loading in main_with_loop)
- `openhands/cli/settings.py` (save_settings_confirmation function)
- `openhands/storage/settings/file_settings_store.py`

issueDTO.title: [GSSoC25] Bug: Password Complexity Rules Not Enforced on Submission
issueDTO.description:
### GitHub Username

kyra-1

### 📌 Issue Title / Suggestion Summary

Bug: Password complexity rules are suggested by the UI but not enforced during registration

### 📝 Detailed Description

## 🔍 What is the Current Behavior?

The current registration form (`register.html`) includes a **password strength bar** that visually represents the complexity of the password.  
It evaluates the following criteria:

- Password **length**
- Presence of **uppercase letters**
- Inclusion of **numbers**
- Usage of **special characters**

Based on these, the bar changes **width** and **color** to indicate strength.  
However, the form submission handler only validates the password's length (must be 8-20 characters) and that the confirmation matches.

---

## 💡 What Change Are You Proposing?    

The current registration form has a bug where it allows the submission of weak passwords like "aaaaaaaa". The password strength meter provides visual feedback on complexity by checking for uppercase letters, numbers, and special characters, but these rules are not actually enforced when the user clicks "Register". I am proposing a change to fix this by ensuring the password complexity rules are mandatory for successful registration.   

---

## 🎯 Why Is This Needed?

This is a functional bug that allows users to create weak and insecure passwords, defeating the purpose of having a password strength indicator and creating a security loophole in the registration process.

## 💭 Proposed Solution 

The solution involves modifying the form submission handler within the register.js file. The validation logic that runs upon form submission will be updated to incorporate the complexity checks already used by the visual strength meter. If the password does not meet these required criteria, the submission will be blocked and an appropriate error message will be displayed to the user.

I???ve reviewed the relevant files and am ready to begin. Please assign this issue to me if approved.

---

## ??? Readiness and Request

I have reviewed the relevant files and am fully prepared to begin implementing this feature.

If this proposal is approved, I would appreciate being **assigned this issue** so I can start contributing to the improvement.


### ??? Contributor Checklist

- [x] I have searched and confirmed this issue has not been reported already.
- [x] I am a registered participant of GSSoC 2025.
- [x] I have starred the repository to support the project.
- [x] I agree to follow the project's [Code of Conduct](../CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md).

issueDTO.title: TechDraw: balloon annotation lacks streamlined features such as orthogonal flag
issueDTO.description:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Problem description

At the moment it is impossible to move/slide the origin (of an annotation) along the chosen line (e.g. a datum), which is often required to be attached to lead lines and/or center lines in real engineering drawings. 

Filled triangles wouldn't stay orthogonal to the lines they are attached to if the angle between the head and the origin is too steep.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c1058d4f-c45b-4770-960f-b1d165f561dc)

The current solution is adjusting the origin's and the head's XY coordinates, which is a bummer. At the moment there is NO solution to misaligned allows (within FreeCAD). Potentially, something like "orthogonal" flag is required.

### Full version info

```shell
OS: Windows 11 build 22621
Word size of FreeCAD: 64-bit
Version: 1.0.0RC1.38642 (Git)
Build type: Release
Branch: (HEAD detached at 1.0rc1)

issueDTO.title: tbc: roll heighthash database into blockheaders
issueDTO.description:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have checked for similar issues.

### Problem

We keep a separate database to map height to hash of blockheaders. This really should be rolled into the blockheaders database which will drastically simplify database locking.

### Suggested solution

- Remove heighthash database
- Reindex all blockheaders and encode heighthash in the same database as follows: `H[32 bit big endian height][32 byte hash]`
- Adjust calls that use heighthash database to dig into blockheaders database instead and index on H[height]`
- Upgrade database +1


### Additional Information

_No response_
comments: Optional for v2

summary.attemptedFixes: No attempted fixes mentioned
summary.otherNotes: No additional information provided

issueDTO.title: tbc: roll blocksmissing database into blocks
issueDTO.description:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have checked for similar issues.

### Problem

We keep a separate table for blocks that are missing during download. When the code was originally written it seemed to make sense to keep this separate but that turned out to make the code more complex. Roll the blocks missing info into the block database as an index.

### Suggested solution

Remove blocksmissing database
Reindex all blocksmissing and encode them in the same database as follows: M[32 bit big endian block height][32 byte block hash]
Adjust calls that use blocksmissing database to dig into blocks database instead and index on M[height][hash]`
Upgrade database +1


### Additional Information

By encoding the height in blocksmissing we can keep track of where we are at and more importantly we can download blocks in order! This is a huge win!
comments: Optional for v2

Arguably take/filter should be ArrayOperations, rather than compute functions. Then it kind of makes sense for them to not fail?

issueDTO.title: Add a method to push struct validity into children
issueDTO.description:
Unlike Arrow's `RecordBatches`, `StructArray` can be "nullable" in two places: in the child arrays and also at the top level. This makes some struct operations tricky - for example, how do you zip two arrays with different top-level validity?

One solution could be to add a method that pushes top-level validity down to the children (assuming all fields are nullable). For example:

`{a: 1, b: 2}, NULL` would become `{a: 1, b: 2}, {a: NULL, b: NULL}`
comments: We have https://github.com/vortex-data/vortex/blob/develop/vortex-array/src/compute/mask.rs#L48, however maybe the faster way is to accept mask in some compute functions and let them decide how to apply it

> We have https://github.com/vortex-data/vortex/blob/develop/vortex-array/src/compute/mask.rs#L48

Sure! But what do you think about adding a separate method for the struct? This feels like a super common usecase - have written this three times in spiral last week

Okay, so what needs to be done here: 
- We need to implement a method to push validity
- We need to add docs
- Method should be tested

I actually wrote an in-place method, feel free to use this as a reference / base on top of that: https://gist.github.com/blaginin/9927afd94a8d5bb272135d0c5dc99652

summary.attemptedFixes: The author has already written an in-place method and provided a reference. Additionally, the comment mentions considering a faster way by accepting a mask in compute functions.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about adding a method to push struct validity into children, specifically handling nullable fields in StructArray and top-level validity. The author has already written an in-place method and provided a reference.

issueDTO.title: Rename `nbytes` and improve docs
comments: This seems like a regression, we used to count the size of metadata at minimum as a baseline size https://github.com/vortex-data/vortex/pull/1549 but we lost it in one of the rewrites
Because nbytes no longer dispatches on the array type but instead is generically implemented for `dyn Array` you can't easily access metadata size

How do you want to count metadata size for arrays that choose not to implement serialization? I don't know that we can simply do better than buffer size in a way that's meaninful to callers. Anything else we do is also approximate.

I was thinking somethinng like `size_of_val(self)` for an array but agree that it's an overestimate. The caller could also add it themselves since you rightly point out that not all arrays will be serializable
On second thought I think this is fixable on the user size if we make sure that nbytes contract is the variable length size of the array. The caller has self so adding size_of_val can be done by them
Fair, then closing!
should we rename the method / better explain it in the docs? 🤔
Yes, we should!
will do

actually, i feel like for memory management systems it would be better to just be honest about the size. e.g., if you have a million `SequenceArrays`, they start to matter even though they have no buffers.

i don't like the idea of handling this in user space, because you can't just add the top-level size - you have to walk all the children and sum them up, which feels painful

@robert3005 what was the reasoning not to do `size_of_val`? 
Alternatively, we can also manually add all required values in each array - which feels a bit verbose but more correct

I think you're right. I was looking at our existing implementation and noticed that the change I wanted to make would only ever add the metadata of top level array, however, it makes sense that for nested arrays this could grow a lot. However, we still have a problem of serialized size could not match the in memory size or you could have arrays that can't be serialized. Let me open a pr to see

I think it makes sense for nbytes == sum size of all buffers. It's a clean, deterministic number. Maybe the follow up here is to document the method as such.

If you want a custom measure, for computeing a cache weight or whatever, then I'd say that's something quite specific to the application. Consumer can define their own extension trait, and implement something over depth_first_iterator.

If you want an exact size, then you're going to have to serialize into byte buffers (which includes _all_ metadata), but obviously that's needlessly expensive for a cache weight.

I'm not convinced you have to ask all users to reimplement the same thing. There's realistically 3 measures here that anyone might want, the variable size (current nbytes), variable size + in memory size (effectively recursively adding size of self), serialized size. We could have the first 2 but we can implement 2 in spiral for now. 3 is potentially hard since you have to shrink all the buffers to only present values.
Updated the issue as we want to update docs and potentially method name. Feels like a good first issue so putting a label for that

issueDTO.title: Intro guide for Vortex
issueDTO.description:
When doing https://github.com/vortex-data/vortex/pull/3906 I couldn't find a way in the documentation to put information about this method - even though debug printing feels like a very important tool for learning a new library

Moreover, as I was getting into the project, I couldn't find a simple cheat sheet on Vortex containing basic ops like:
- how to create a new array (for different types, for example that you want to use VarBin for string)
- how to print them 
- how to iterate them
- how to get individual element
- how to modify an array
- how to write it to the file
- and so on

To be fair, some of those are covered in examples, but it's very slow to iterate over all of them checking if they have something you need. 

I think we should have this information as a single page in two ways: 
- pretty formatted and concise for humans, with some comments and explanation
-  in `vortex.dev/llm.txt` for LLMs. Example: `https://alloy.rs/llms-full.txt` and https://alloy.rs/introduction/prompting

issueDTO.title: Add organization member listing
issueDTO.description:
### Summary

The front-end lacks showing organization member listing on the organization details page (`/settings/organizations/[slug]`), however, all the pieces that are needed to implement showing the member list are available.

By this point, the organization details should be in the related slice on the front-end, including the `teams` (or `roles`) of the organization. Unfortunately, the organization members are not stored with their team details, so it must be fetched separately, one by one. This is not the most efficient, especially not for several teams, but for the MVP it is ???good enough???.

Since the Organization API returns only the team IDs that the organization have, to get the team details, a call must be made to the [Organization Roles API](https://github.com/opcotech/elemo/blob/main/api/openapi/openapi.yaml#L1996-L2032) which returns the team details. To get the members of a given team, use the [Organization Role Members API](https://github.com/opcotech/elemo/blob/main/api/openapi/openapi.yaml#L2151-L2186). The endpoint returns the list of members per role. These calls are independent (as both requires the organization ID and/or role ID, which is already available).

With the information returned from these APIs, add the list of members with the following details about them below the company details: profile picture, name, email, status. Either group the members by their role or add a badge next to their name with the role name. The members which has ???deleted??? status should be listed as well, however, those members should be at the bottom of the list. If the current user is in the list, mark it with a green ???you??? badge next to its name. The badge is [available locally](https://github.com/opcotech/elemo/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#web-component-design) in Storybook.

There is no need to bother with member management (add/remote/change role). That's not in scope for this issue.

Blocked on #155.

_End-to-end tests are not strictly necessary, but highly welcomed._

### Example Use-cases

- As an organization admin, I want to see who is in the team and what roles do they have.
- As an organization member, I want to see my peers, so if escalation is needed, I know who to contact.

### Drawbacks

As we have no endpoint to return the list of members combined with their roles, the load time for that page will be bad, but not unmanageable.

issueDTO.title: UI - Graph option selector DagRun and Versions
issueDTO.description:
### Body

When we select a DagRun, automatically the Version will be changed to match the one of the dagrun and display the relevant structure of the dagrun, that's great.

When we do the opposite, for instance we select different versions for a specific dagrun it will display the version structure and try to match the execution of the DagRun on it. It makes sense for DagRun with multiple versions, but I don't think we should be able to explore DagVersions that are not part of the selected dagrun at all. 

It makes it hard to follow when we start playing with the `version selector` when a DagRun is selected. (Is the DagVersion that I have selected part of the DagRun.dag_versions, or am I watching a completely unrelated structure)


For instance in the following image I have the `v2` structure displayed for a DagRun that actually only has `v4` part of his versions. The output graph doesn't make much sense.
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fb45d6a5-514f-464e-b756-39c8b0a70c39)


I do not know yet what is the best way to address this, any idea is welcome.
### Committer

- [x] I acknowledge that I am a maintainer/committer of the Apache Airflow project.

issueDTO.title: socks proxy support
issueDTO.description:
### Feature request description

Hi. I'm trying to run ramalama from China, where most of the free internet is only accessible over a proxy. Naive attempts to invoke a proxy with all_proxy fail:
```
$ export all_proxy="socks5h://localhost:1080"
```
```
$ ramalama rag ~/test.md localhost/test.md
Converting test.md.pdf .   2025-07-24 11:18:52.081 | ERROR    | fastembed.common.model_management:download_model:430 - Could not download model from HuggingFace: (ProtocolError('Connection aborted.', ConnectionResetError(104, 'Connection reset by peer')), '(Request ID: b19d6dd2-5b1f-40d3-9670-d54511639529)') Falling back to other sources.
2025-07-24 11:18:52.081 | ERROR    | fastembed.common.model_management:download_model:452 - Could not download model from either source, sleeping for 3.0 seconds, 2 retries left.
...
```

It would be great to have support for a socks proxy (actually socks5h, so that the DNS queries are also proxied).

### Suggest potential solution

_No response_

### Have you considered any alternatives?

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_
comments: Interested in opening a PR to add support?
I can take a look, but I don't really have an idea how it would be done best. Perhaps if all downloads were made with curl, proxies would just work, but is it sensible to change everything to curl?

> I can take a look, but I don't really have an idea how it would be done best. Perhaps if all downloads were made with curl, proxies would just work, but is it sensible to change everything to curl?

Short answer, sadly no it is not sensible to change everything to curl...
Googling this says that Python should be supporting ALL_PROXY out of the box with the http calls.
What version of RamaLama are  you using?

> What version of RamaLama are you using?

0.11.1

For me, googling shows that urllib.request needs a little bit persuasion to work with socks proxies:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63970912/urllib-request-with-socks5-proxy

A short example from an AI (not verified) is:
```python
import sockslib
import socket
import urllib.request

sockslib.set_default_proxy(('127.0.0.1', 1080))
socket.socket = sockslib.SocksSocket

html = urllib.request.urlopen('https://huggingface.co').read()
```

This works (with pysocks):
```python
import socks
import socket
import urllib.request

socks.set_default_proxy(socks.SOCKS5, 127.0.0.1, 1080)
socket.socket = socks.socksocket

resp = urllib.request.urlopen('https://ifconfig.co/ip')
print(resp.read().decode())
```

But I'm not sure how to make it work in ramalama. I tried editing https://github.com/containers/ramalama/blob/main/ramalama/http_client.py but without any luck yet
@ericcurtin Thoughts?

A short test with this file:
```python
import urllib.request

resp = urllib.request.urlopen('https://ifconfig.co/country')
print(resp.read().decode())
```
and an http/https/socks5 proxy on port 1080.

```
$ python proxy-test.py 
China
```

```
$ all_proxy="socks5h://127.0.0.1:1080" python proxy-test.py 
China
```

```
$ https_proxy="127.0.0.1:1080" python proxy-test.py 
Germany
```

So `urllib.request` picks up an https proxy but does not pick up a socks proxy. The https proxies have a very limited use in China because dns lookup of forbidden websites (like huggingface) is poisoned, and we have to use a socks5h proxy so that the dns lookups go through it
Any idea on how to work around this?

> Any idea on how to work around this?

I found that `requests` (https://docs.python-requests.org) support socks proxies. With `pip install 'requests[socks]'` the following returns the expected result:
```python
import requests
r = requests.get('https://ifconfig.co/country')
print(r.text)
```
```
$ all_proxy="socks5h://127.0.0.1:1080" python proxy-test.py 
Germany
```

I don't know if a switch from urllib to requests is sensible
@ericcurtin @olliewalsh @engelmi WDYT?
No objection from me. I expect requests is still more widely used than urllib - the differences are far less significant than they used to be though.
@johonan interested in opening a PR to change from urllib to requests?

If it was me, I'd just write a wrapper around urllib rather than drag in a new dependancy, but requests seems like it's packaged in RHEL, etc. so I guess it's reasonable here, this will be a significant change. Things like progress bars etc. depend on calls specific to urllib, I think doing wrappers like below would be better, but happy to leave that decision to the implementer:

```
import socket
import urllib.request

# Minimal SOCKS5 handshake implementation
def socks5_connect(sock, proxy_addr, proxy_port, dest_addr, dest_port):
    sock.connect((proxy_addr, proxy_port))
    # Greet
    sock.sendall(b"\x05\x01\x00")
    resp = sock.recv(2)
    if resp != b"\x05\x00":
        raise Exception("SOCKS5 proxy did not accept handshake")
    # Connect request
    req = b"\x05\x01\x00\x03" + bytes([len(dest_addr)]) + dest_addr.encode() + dest_port.to_bytes(2, 'big')
    sock.sendall(req)
    resp = sock.recv(10)
    if resp[1] != 0x00:
        raise Exception("SOCKS5 proxy connection failed")
    # Now sock is connected through the proxy

# Monkeypatch socket
_orig_socket = socket.socket

class Socks5Socket(socket.socket):
    def connect(self, address):
        proxy_addr = '127.0.0.1'
        proxy_port = 1080
        dest_addr, dest_port = address
        socks5_connect(self, proxy_addr, proxy_port, dest_addr, dest_port)

socket.socket = Socks5Socket

# Now urllib will use our patched socket
print(urllib.request.urlopen("http://example.com").read())

# Restore socket afterwards
socket.socket = _orig_socket
```
